title: Concluding Questions
material: Concluding Questions Reconstruct, reimagine, reignite: consider the works of David Irvine as examples of how new art can be made from old things, even those found in thrift stores. Will the future be built from bits of the past, or from materials we haven’t even imagined yet? What would you prefer to see? Listen to the song “Section 52 (Morning Sun, I Built the Stairs)” by the Polyphonic Spree, and then consider whether it feels more like a song about beginnings, endings, or starting over again. Is it optimistic about what comes next? Are you? Work with your team to imagine yourselves reuniting in 20 years; you can even use AI tools online to create images of what you’ll like in the future. What kind of world will you be living in, and what sorts of people will you become? Which of your dreams, if any, do you think will need reigniting?

additional-material.name: works of David Irvine
additional-material.text:
David Irvine, a Toronto-based artist, has gained recognition for his innovative approach to art through the practice of "upcycling" thrift store paintings. His work involves repurposing old prints, which he finds nostalgic and appealing due to their vintage frames. Initially, Irvine would paint over these canvases, but he later began to incorporate pop culture figures into the original artworks, creating a juxtaposition between traditional scenes and contemporary icons. Over five years, he has transformed hundreds of paintings, often inspired by spontaneous ideas that come to him while viewing the original pieces.

Irvine's artistic process is characterized by a playful blend of humor and nostalgia. He often integrates well-known characters, such as Darth Vader and Pac-Man, into serene landscapes or classic portraits, which he describes as a way to make the old feel new again. His works are not merely alterations but rather thoughtful additions that provoke a dialogue between the past and present. Irvine emphasizes the importance of maintaining the original style and color palette of the paintings to ensure that his contributions feel cohesive rather than disjointed.

The artist's choice to work primarily with prints and lithographs stems from a respect for original artworks, which he prefers not to alter. This decision reflects a broader commentary on the value of art and the stories embedded within these thrifted pieces. By upcycling, Irvine not only breathes new life into forgotten artworks but also invites viewers to reconsider their perceptions of value and creativity in art.

Irvine's work resonates with audiences due to its relatable themes and humor, often drawing connections to shared cultural experiences. His unique approach to combining the old with the new has garnered attention, highlighting the potential for creativity in the realm of upcycling and the importance of sustainability in art. Through his paintings, Irvine encourages a reflection on nostalgia, pop culture, and the evolving nature of artistic expression.

additional-material.name: Section 52 (Morning Sun, I Built the Stairs)
additional-material.text:
"Section 52 (Morning Sun, I Built The Stairs)" is a musical piece by The Polyphonic Spree, released on September 18, 2023. This track is part of their album "Salvage Enterprise," which showcases the band's signature orchestral pop sound characterized by lush arrangements and uplifting melodies. The song reflects themes of hope and perseverance, encapsulated in its title, which suggests a journey of building and overcoming obstacles.

The composition features a rich tapestry of instrumentation, including strings, brass, and choral elements, creating a vibrant and expansive auditory experience. The lyrics convey a sense of introspection and resilience, inviting listeners to reflect on their own experiences of growth and the challenges faced along the way. The Polyphonic Spree's unique style, which blends elements of rock, pop, and classical music, is evident throughout the piece, making it both engaging and thought-provoking.

The release of "Section 52" has garnered attention within the music community, accumulating over 15,000 views on YouTube. The song has resonated particularly with audiences involved in academic competitions, such as the World Scholar's Cup (WSC), where it has been used as a study aid. This connection highlights the song's versatility and its ability to inspire and motivate listeners in various contexts.

Overall, "Section 52 (Morning Sun, I Built The Stairs)" exemplifies The Polyphonic Spree's artistic vision, combining intricate musicality with meaningful lyrics. The track not only contributes to the band's discography but also serves as a source of encouragement for individuals navigating their own paths in life.
